## Abstract Create Demo

The `abstractCreateDemo` function helps you create structured demo factories that work seamlessly with the [`CodeHighlighter`](../../components/code-highlighter/page.mdx) component ecosystem. It provides a standardized way to create demos that combine component previews with code display, making it easier to build consistent documentation interfaces.

  - Implementation
  - Global Dependencies
    - Loader Configuration
  - Related

</details>

## Abstract Create Demo Client

The `abstractCreateDemoClient` function helps you create client-side demo providers that manage external dependencies for live component demos. It creates provider components that supply externals context to child components, enabling dynamic code execution in the browser.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
  - When to Use Demo Clients

  - Client Provider Features
  - Configuration Options
    - AbstractCreateDemoClientOptions
    - CreateDemoClientMeta
  - Externals Context
  - Best Practices
  - Example: Complete Live Demo Setup
  - Related

</details>

## Create Demo Data

The `createDemoData` utility creates structured demo metadata and component data for use with the [`CodeHighlighter`](../components/code-highlighter/page.mdx) system. It processes demo URLs, components, and metadata to create data objects that can be consumed by demo factories and code highlighting systems.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Features
  - Usage
    - Global Demo Data Structure
      - Global Variant Matching
  - When to Use
  - Related

</details>

## Create Sitemap

The `createSitemap` factory function defines sitemap data for documentation sites. It works with the webpack loader for build-time precomputation in Next.js builds.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
  - API Reference
    - Parameters
    - Returns
    - Behavior
  - Runtime Loading
  - File Structure
  - Type Definitions
    - CreateSitemapMeta
    - Sitemap
    - SitemapSectionData
    - SitemapPage
  - Configuration
    - Skip Precomputation
    - Webpack Loader Setup
  - Integration with Search
  - Populating the Sitemap
  - Related

</details>

## HAST Utilities

The `hastUtils` module provides utilities for converting between HAST (Hypertext Abstract Syntax Tree) nodes, strings, and React JSX elements. These utilities are essential for processing syntax-highlighted code and converting markdown/HTML structures to React components.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Features
  - Usage
  - API
    - `hastToJsx(hast: HastNodes): React.ReactNode`
    - `hastOrJsonToJsx(hastOrJson: HastNodes | { hastJson: string }): React.ReactNode`
    - `stringOrHastToString(source: string | HastNodes | { hastJson: string }): string`
    - `stringOrHastToJsx(source: string | HastNodes | { hastJson: string }, highlighted?: boolean): React.ReactNode`
  - When to Use

</details>

## Load Code Variant

The `loadCodeVariant` module provides utilities for loading, processing, and transforming code variants with support for syntax highlighting, TypeScript-to-JavaScript transformation, extra files, and metadata management.

## Load Precomputed Code Highlighter

The precompute loader is a Webpack/Turbopack loader that enables build-time optimization of code examples by processing demo files and precomputing syntax highlighting, TypeScript transformations, and dependency resolution.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
    - Key Features
  - Configuration
    - Recommended: withDocsInfra Plugin
    - Manual Next.js Setup
    - File Structure
  - Usage
    - Basic Demo File
    - Multiple Variants
    - Options
    - Custom Factory Functions
  - Processing Pipeline
    - 1\. Parse Factory Call
    - 2\. Resolve File Paths
    - 3\. Process Variants
    - 4\. Inserts Precompute Value
  - Output Structure
  - Error Handling
    - Single Factory Function per File
    - Missing Files
    - Invalid Function Signature
  - Benefits
    - Build-time Optimization
    - Developer Experience
    - Performance
  - Best Practices
    - File Organization
    - Dependency Management
    - Configuration

## Load Precomputed Code Highlighter Client

The precomputed code client loader is a Webpack/Turbopack loader that enables build-time optimization of client-side demo components by processing demo client files and precomputing external dependencies for live editing environments.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
    - Key Features
  - Configuration
    - Recommended: withDocsInfra Plugin
    - Manual Next.js Setup
    - File Structure
  - Usage
    - Basic Demo Client File
    - With Options
    - Multiple Variants
    - Custom Client Factory Functions
  - Processing Pipeline
    - 1\. Parse Factory Call
    - 2\. Resolve Variant Paths
    - 3\. Collect Externals
    - 4\. Inject Externals
  - Output Structure
    - Externals Format
  - Error Handling
    - Single Client Factory Function per File
    - Missing Variant Files
    - Invalid Function Signature
    - Skip Precompute
  - Benefits
    - Build-time Externals Resolution
    - Live Editing Support
    - Performance
  - Best Practices
    - File Organization
    - Client Factory Design
    - Configuration
  - Related Documentation

</details>

## Load Precomputed Sitemap

The precomputed sitemap loader is a Webpack/Turbopack loader that processes markdown files at build time to create optimized search indexes and navigation data. It extracts metadata from documentation pages and generates structured sitemap data with Orama search schema.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:

    - Key Features
  - Configuration

    - Skip Precomputation
  - Processing Pipeline
    - 1\. Parse Factory Call
    - 2\. Extract Path Metadata
    - 3\. Parse Markdown Files
    - 4\. Optimize Data
    - 5\. Generate Schema
    - 6\. Replace Factory Call
  - Output Structure
  - Orama Integration
  - Path-Based Metadata

## Load Server Code Meta

The `loadServerCodeMeta` utility parses demo files to extract variant information and resolves file paths for code metadata. It reads demo index files, finds `createDemo` factory calls, and builds a `Code` object mapping variant names to their file URLs.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Basic Usage
  - Common Patterns
    - Single Variant Demo
    - Multiple Variants Demo
    - Named Exports
  - Advanced Usage
    - Custom Implementation
    - Integration with CodeHighlighter
  - API Reference
    - loadServerCodeMeta
    - createLoadServerCodeMeta
    - Type Definitions
  - How It Works
  - When to Use
  - Related

## Load Server Page Index

The `loadServerPageIndex` utility reads a markdown file and extracts page metadata for use in sitemaps. It parses the markdown content, extracts titles, descriptions, sections, and keywords, and derives additional metadata like URL prefix from the file path.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Basic Usage
  - Common Patterns
    - Loading a Single Page Index
    - With Custom Root Context
  - Path Processing
    - Path Segment to Title
    - URL Prefix Generation
    - Filtered Path Segments
  - API Reference
    - loadServerPageIndex
    - createLoadServerPageIndex
    - pathSegmentToTitle
    - extractPrefixAndTitle
    - stripTitleMarkdown
  - Type Definitions
    - SitemapSectionData
    - SitemapPage
    - SitemapSection
    - CreateLoadServerPageIndexOptions
  - Data Optimization
    - Stripped Fields
    - Normalized Fields
    - Example Output
  - Related

</details>

## Load Server Sitemap

The `loadServerSitemap` utility parses sitemap index files to load page metadata at runtime. It reads the sitemap index file, finds [`createSitemap`](../create-sitemap/page.mdx) factory calls, resolves page imports, and builds a complete `Sitemap` object with schema and data.

    - createLoadServerSitemap
    - createSitemapSchema
  - Type Definitions
    - Sitemap
    - SitemapSectionData
    - SitemapPage
  - Comparison: Build-Time vs Runtime
  - Related

</details>

## Load Server Source

The `loadServerSource` utility reads source files from the filesystem and analyzes their dependencies, extracting imports and resolving relative file paths. It processes JavaScript/TypeScript files to build dependency trees and prepare code for documentation and live demos.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Features
  - Usage
  - Configuration
  - Import Storage Modes
    - `'flat'` (default)
    - `'canonical'`
    - `'import'`
  - Return Value
  - How It Works
  - Examples
    - Loading a JavaScript File
    - Loading with External Dependencies
    - Loading a CSS File
    - Using Custom storeAt Mode
  - When to Use
  - Related

[Read more](./load-server-source/page.mdx)

## Loader Utilities

The loader utilities provide a comprehensive set of functions for resolving, parsing, and processing import statements in JavaScript/TypeScript code. These utilities are essential for building systems that need to analyze and transform code imports, such as code highlighters, bundlers, and documentation generators.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
  - Architecture
  - Core Functions
    - parseImportsAndComments
    - resolveModulePath
    - resolveModulePaths
    - resolveImportResult
    - resolveVariantPaths
    - processRelativeImports
    - getFileNameFromUrl
    - extractNameAndSlugFromUrl
    - externalsToPackages
    - rewriteImports
    - rewriteImportsToNull
    - removeImports
  - Path Conversion Utilities
    - fileUrlToPortablePath
    - portablePathToFileUrl
  - Language Detection Utilities
    - getLanguageFromExtension
    - normalizeLanguage
    - languageMap / languageAliasMap
  - Module Detection
    - isJavaScriptModule
  - Complete Pipeline Example
  - Type Definitions
    - Import Types
    - Resolution Types
    - Processing Types
    - Extension Constants
  - Performance Optimizations
    - Filesystem Access Optimization
  - Error Handling
  - Testing

</details>

## Parse Source

The `parseSource` utility parses source code into HAST (Hypertext Abstract Syntax Tree) nodes with syntax highlighting using [Starry Night](https://github.com/wooorm/starry-night). It converts code into highlighted HTML structures for display in documentation and demos.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Basic Usage
  - Common Patterns
    - Highlighting Different Languages
    - Processing Multiple Files
    - Unsupported File Types
  - Advanced Usage
    - Global Instance Pattern
    - Integration with Code Highlighter
  - API Reference
    - createParseSource
    - parseSource
    - Type Definitions
  - How It Works
  - Supported Languages
  - Error Handling
    - Uninitialized Parser
    - Empty Content
  - When to Use
  - Related

</details>

## Sync Page Index

The `syncPageIndex` function automatically maintains index pages by extracting metadata from documentation pages and updating parent directory indexes. It's designed to work with Next.js file-based routing, keeping navigation indexes in sync as pages are added or modified.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
  - Basic Usage
  - Common Patterns
    - Batch Updates
    - Recursive Parent Updates
    - Include/Exclude Patterns
    - CI Validation Mode
  - Generated Index Format
  - API Reference
    - syncPageIndex
    - SyncPageIndexOptions
    - PageMetadata
  - Extra Metadata
    - Tags
    - Parts and Exports
    - External Links
  - Helper Functions
    - markdownToMetadata
    - mergeMetadataMarkdown
  - File Locking
  - Route Group Handling
  - Related

## Transform HTML Code

A rehype plugin that transforms `<pre>` elements containing `<code>` blocks into precomputed data for the CodeHighlighter component. This plugin extracts source code from HTML, processes it through syntax highlighting and transformations, then stores the results for efficient client-side rendering.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
  - Key Features
  - Installation & Usage
    - With Next.js and MDX
  - Input Examples
    - Single Code Block
    - Multiple Code Variants (Different Languages)
    - Custom Variant Names
    - Custom Filenames
    - Code Block Transformations
  - Output
  - Data Attributes
    - Reserved Attributes (handled internally)
    - Custom Attributes (passed to content component)
  - Variant Naming
  - Supported Languages
  - Integration with transformMarkdownCodeVariants
    - Complete Example

</details>

## Transform Markdown Blockquote Callouts

The `transformMarkdownBlockquoteCallouts` plugin is a Remark plugin that enables GitHub-style callout blocks in markdown. It transforms blockquotes with special markers (like `> [!NOTE]`) into HTML blockquotes with a `data-callout-type` attribute, making it easy to style and render callouts in your documentation.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Features
  - Supported Callout Types
    - Default Colors
  - Example
    - How to Write a Callout in Markdown
    - Live Callout Examples
  - Usage
  - Integration
  - Best Practices
  - Related

</details>

## Transform Markdown Code

A remark plugin that transforms markdown code blocks into HTML structures with enhanced metadata support. This plugin handles both individual code blocks with options and multi-variant code examples. It's the **first stage** in a processing pipeline, typically followed by [`transformHtmlCode`](/functions/transformHtmlCode) for final rendering.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
  - Key Features
  - Installation & Usage
    - With Next.js and MDX

    - Individual Code Blocks with Options
    - Basic Variants (variant=name)
    - Labeled Variants (variant-group=name)
    - Different Languages
    - Custom Properties
  - Plugin Behavior
    - Individual Code Block Processing
    - Grouping Rules
    - Label Extraction (variant-group only)
    - Language Support
  - Integration with transformHtmlCode
    - Complete Pipeline Example
  - Common Use Cases
    - Individual Code Enhancement
    - Package Manager Examples
    - Framework Comparisons
    - Configuration Files
    - API Examples
  - Configuration
  - Troubleshooting
    - Individual Code Blocks Not Processing
    - Code Blocks Not Grouping
    - Labels Not Working
    - Missing Language Classes
  - Technical Details
    - HTML Structure
    - Data Attributes
    - Performance
  - Implementation Details
    - AST Transformation
    - Language Detection
    - Metadata Parsing
  - Error Handling
  - Performance Considerations

## Transform Markdown Demo Links

A remark plugin that automatically cleans up "[See Demo]" links and horizontal rules that follow Demo components in markdown documentation. This plugin identifies Demo components (without `.Title`) and removes associated navigation elements to create cleaner documentation.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Overview
  - Key Features
  - Installation & Usage
    - With docs-infra
  - Syntax Examples
    - Basic Demo Component Cleanup
    - Demo Component with Properties
    - Horizontal Rule Only Cleanup
  - Demo Component Detection
    - Demo.Title Exclusion
  - Plugin Behavior
    - Processing Rules
    - Element Matching
    - Content Preservation
  - Common Use Cases
    - Documentation Cleanup
    - Migration from External Demos
    - Streamlined Reading Experience
  - Configuration
  - Troubleshooting
    - Links Not Being Removed
    - Demo Components Not Detected
    - Unexpected Content Removal

</details>

## Transform Markdown Metadata

A remark plugin that extracts metadata from MDX files and optionally updates parent directory index pages. This plugin automatically collects page titles, descriptions, keywords, and hierarchical section structures to create searchable, navigable documentation indexes.

## Transform Markdown Relative Paths

The `transformMarkdownRelativePaths` plugin is a Remark plugin that automatically transforms relative markdown links to work seamlessly in both development environments (VSCode, GitHub) and production builds. It strips page file extensions and converts relative paths to absolute URLs.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Features
  - How It Works
    - URL Transformations
  - Best Practices for Linking
    - Use Relative Links with page.mdx
    - Advanced Example with Fragments
    - Directory Structure Examples
    - Why This Approach Works
  - Integration
    - Automatic with Next.js Plugin
    - Manual Integration
  - Advanced Usage
    - With Query Parameters and Fragments
    - Nested Directory Navigation
  - Configuration
  - Examples
    - Component Cross-References
    - Function Documentation Links
    - Index Page Navigation
  - Benefits
  - Related

## Transform Typescript To Javascript

The `transformTypescriptToJavascript` utility transforms TypeScript/TSX code into JavaScript/JSX using Babel, preserving formatting and automatically generating JavaScript variants for documentation and demos.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Features
  - Usage
  - Transformer Configuration
  - Advanced Configuration
  - How It Works
  - Supported Features
    - TypeScript Constructs Removed
    - Preserved Features
  - File Extension Mapping
  - Example Transformations
  - When to Use
  - Related
  - Implementation Notes

</details>

## With Docs Infra

The `withDocsInfra` function is a Next.js configuration plugin that sets up webpack loaders, Turbopack rules, and page extensions required for MUI docs infrastructure. It automatically configures code highlighting loaders for demo files and provides sensible defaults for documentation sites.

<details>

<summary>Outline</summary>

- Sections:
  - Features
  - Basic Usage
  - Advanced Configuration
  - Default Configurations
    - Page Extensions
    - Demo File Patterns
  - MDX Integration
    - Controlling Index Generation
  - Default MDX Plugins
    - Remark Plugins (Markdown processing)
    - Rehype Plugins (HTML processing)
  - Configuration Options
    - WithDocsInfraOptions
    - DocsInfraMdxOptions
  - Example: Custom Demo Structure
  - How It Works
  - Integration Example
  - Automatic Index Generation
